newsitem.title: GERMANY: Buba says govt six-month cash deficit deepens.
newsitem.headline: Buba says govt six-month cash deficit deepens.

text.p: The German federal government ran up a cash deficit of 50.5 billion marks in the 1997 first half, about 12.5 billion marks higher than in the 1996 period, the Bundesbank said in its monthly report for July.

The German central bank said the cash deficit in June, which it termed "a big tax month" due to quarterly tax payments, narrowed by about 2.5 billion marks but failed to offset the weak position at the start of the year.
In June itself, the cash deficit was "a good 1/2 billion marks", despite the high tax inflows, it said.
The report said cash inflows during the period from January to June rose 6.5 percent but that outgoing payments rose almost 10 percent.
The Bundesbank also said net borrowing by German federal, regional and local authorities in the first five months of 1997 rose about 25.5 billion marks to 63 billion marks.
The report said that as in previous months the federal government was the top borrower in capital markets with an increase of a net 11 billion marks in May and 14-1/2 billion marks in June.
The Bundesbank figures on cash deficit refer only to payments and withdrawals from government accounts with the German central bank.
The figures differ from the government's fiscal statistics because they record transactions as and when they are made rather than when they are included in the government budget.
They also include transactions for the European Union which are not registered in the budget.
